questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the OPD with a painless, very slowly growing mass of the right third finger. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enchondroma

 

ENCHONDROMA

 

  • When chondromas arise in the medullary canal, they’re referred to as enchondroma.
  • Enchondroma is benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand.
  • They are seen after age of skeletal maturity.
  • These are the centric, non-expansile or minimally expansile tumors with marginal sclerosis.

 

 

  • Multiple enchondromas is also known as Ollier’s syndrome.
  • Multiple enchondromas + subcutaneous Hemangioma + Phlebolith = Maffucci syndrome

 

 

Maffucci syndrome: A) Hemangiomas, B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in < 2% solitary cases, 30% in ollier disease and 100% in maffucci’s syndrome.
  • Treatment is by extended curettage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Osteoclastoma is located at the epiphysis. The most common location is distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Patient presents with swelling and vague pain. Radiographic examination reveals bony swelling, eccentrically located at the end of the bone and soap bubble appearance on X-ray. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex, however, intraarticular extension is rare as the subchondral bone usually remains intact. Treatment is done by extended curettage by PMMA or phenol or liquid nitrogen and bone grafting – the procedure of choice. 

 

 

Option D. Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone. It is a developmental malformation and not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. It is thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodule. X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur. Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap, a result of development malformation. An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity. Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally. Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation, fracture through stalk or pedunculated (narrow based) lesion, sarcomatous change and Impingement of neighbouring structure, e.g. nerve, vessel, etc. Treatment: en bloc resection – extra-periosteal resection

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enchondromas as painless, very slowly growing masses that commonly affect the short bones of the hand.

choices.text: Inside the membrane
At the C-terminal
At the N-terminal
Both inside the membrane and at C- terminal

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inside the membrane

 

The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein is located inside the membrane.

 

These sequences usually have methionine as the terminal amino acid.

 

Transmembrane proteins are integral proteins that span across the plasma/ endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. They are classified into types 1 to 4. –

 

Type 1 membrane proteins have a cleavable N-terminal signal sequence outside the cell, a transmembrane sequence that is usually situated close to the C-terminus and the C-terminus facing inside the cell, e.g., low-density lipoprotein receptor.

 

Type 2 membrane proteins have the N-terminal towards the cytosol and the C-terminal towards the exterior, e.g., transferrin receptor.

 

Type 3 membrane proteins are identical to type 1 but have a shorter N terminal, e.g., cytochrome P450 enzyme complexes.

 

Type 4 membrane proteins consist of 7 alpha helices traversing the membrane, e.g., glucose transporters and G-protein-coupled receptors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. At the C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is not located at the C-terminal.

 

Option C. At the N-terminal: This is incorrect as well. In type 2 membrane proteins, the N-terminal is facing the cytoplasm, but the signaling sequence itself is located inside the membrane.

 

Option D. Both inside the membrane and at C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence is located specifically inside the membrane, not at the C-terminal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is located inside the membrane, crucial for the proper orientation and insertion of the protein.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV-positive male arrives at the hospital complaining of blurred vision and floaters in his left eye. Fundus examination reveals a pizza pie appearance and cotton wool spots, leading to a diagnosis of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ganciclovir

 

Ganciclovir is the most appropriate treatment for cytomegalovirus retinitis in an HIV-positive patient. It is an antiviral medication specifically effective against CMV, working to inhibit viral replication and slow the progression of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotrimoxazole: This is an antibiotic combination used for bacterial infections and prophylaxis of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in HIV patients, not for CMV retinitis.

 

Option C. Tenofovir: Part of antiretroviral therapy for HIV, but not specifically used for treating CMV retinitis.

 

Option D. Acyclovir: While effective against herpes simplex and varicella-zoster viruses, acyclovir is less effective against CMV. Ganciclovir is the preferred treatment for CMV retinitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ganciclovir is the most appropriate treatment for cytomegalovirus retinitis in HIV-positive patients, as it effectively inhibits CMV replication and helps preserve vision.

questions.text: Identify the classification used and grade of the shown injury in a child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gartland’s classification Type III

 

The X-ray provided shows a Supracondylar fracture of the humerus, which is classified using the Gartland classification system. The Gartland classification is specifically for supracondylar fractures, particularly in children.

 

  • Gartland Type III refers to a completely displaced fracture, with no cortical contact between the fragments. There may be either medial or lateral displacement, as seen in this case.
  • The Salter-Harris classification is used for epiphyseal plate injuries, not for supracondylar fractures. Therefore, it is not applicable in this scenario.

 

To summarize:

 

  • Gartland Type I: Undisplaced fracture.
  • Gartland Type II: Displaced fracture with the posterior cortex intact.
  • Gartland Type III: Displaced fracture with no cortical contact (either medial or lateral displacement).
  • Gartland Type IV: An intraoperative diagnosis where the periosteum is damaged both anteriorly and posteriorly, requiring more complex reduction techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salter-Harris classification Type III: Incorrect because the injury in question is not an epiphyseal fracture. Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate fractures, not supracondylar fractures.

 

Option C. Gartland’s classification Type IV: Incorrect because Gartland Type IV is an intraoperative diagnosis, which is not apparent in the provided X-ray.

 

Option D. Salter-Harris classification Type IV: Again, incorrect because this classification system pertains to epiphyseal injuries, and the X-ray shows a supracondylar fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gartland classification is specifically used for supracondylar humerus fractures in children, while the Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate (epiphyseal) fractures.

 

Gartland classification Supracondylar humerus

 

  • Type 1: Undisplaced
  • Type 2: Displaced with posterior hinge intact
  • Type 3a: Displaced fracture with lateral hinge broken (PM)
  • Type 3b: Displaced fracture with medial hinge broken (PL)
  • Type 4: Completely displaced with both anterior and posterior periosteum avulsed (Intra-operative finding)

 

 

Salter-Harris classification of epiphyseal injuries

 

  • Type I: Fracture line is entirely with in Physis causing epiphyseal slip
  • Type II: Fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis (Thurston-Holland’s fragment sign)
  • Type III: Fracture line extends from physis into the Epiphysis causing epiphyseal split
  • Type IV: Fracture line extends across the Epiphysis,  (articular surface), Physis, and metaphysis
  • Type V: Crush injury of physis with initially normal X-rays

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing district data to determine which areas should be prioritized for tuberculosis (TB) interventions. According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), which of the following HIV-TB prevalence rates would categorize a district as high-priority? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) >10%

 

  • According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), districts are categorized based on specific criteria to prioritize TB interventions.
  • One of these criteria is the prevalence of HIV-TB co-infection.
  • High HIV-TB Prevalence: A district is categorized as high-priority if more than 10% of TB patients tested are known to be HIV positive.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen
Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

 

The image shows encapsulated yeast cells characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans. This fungal pathogen primarily affects the lungs, causing pneumonia as its initial manifestation. After infecting the lungs, it can disseminate to other organs, most notably the central nervous system, where it causes meningitis. The lung involvement is typically the first and most common site of infection for Cryptococcus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen: Incorrect. Cryptococcus neoformans appears as round yeast cells with a characteristic capsule. It does not form pseudohyphae, which are more commonly associated with Candida species.

 

Option C. Humans are the only reservoir: Incorrect. The main environmental reservoirs for Cryptococcus neoformans are bird droppings (especially pigeons) and certain trees like eucalyptus. Humans are not considered reservoirs for this organism.

 

Option D. Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900: Incorrect. Severe cryptococcal infections are typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly HIV patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/μL, not 900.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans most commonly affects the lungs as the primary site of infection, followed by potential dissemination to other organs, especially the central nervous system.

questions.text: Which of the following can grow in an acidic pH? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lactobacilli

 

Among the given options, lactobacilli is the one that can grow in an acidic pH.

 

It is a gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic, non-motile, non-spore-forming bacterium. Lactobacillus derives lactic acid from glucose, creating an acidic environment and thus can grow in an acidic medium. It is found in the vagina as part of its normal microbiota.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Incorrect, as Vibrio species typically prefer alkaline conditions, such as those found in seawater.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Incorrect, Salmonella bacteria prefer a neutral to slightly acidic environment but do not thrive in highly acidic conditions.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect, Shigella, like Salmonella, is more adapted to neutral or slightly acidic environments and does not generally grow well in highly acidic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactobacilli's ability to grow in acidic environments is crucial for their role in maintaining healthy microbial flora in certain parts of the human body, such as the vagina, and is also exploited in the fermentation of various food products.

questions.text: A patient with a mood disorder has been on medication and presents with new-onset liver dysfunction and hyperammonemia. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Valproate

 

Valproate (valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant and mood-stabilizing drug used to treat seizures, bipolar disorder, and to prevent migraine headaches. However, it is known to potentially cause hepatotoxicity (liver dysfunction) and hyperammonemia, especially when used in combination with other anticonvulsants or in patients with preexisting liver disease. Hepatotoxicity may be dose-dependent or idiosyncratic, and its risk is increased in the first six months of treatment, with higher doses, and with multiple antiepileptic drug regimens. Hyperammonemia occurs due to valproate’s interference with the urea cycle in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamotrigine: While lamotrigine can have side effects, it is more commonly associated with skin rashes and is not known to cause liver dysfunction and hyperammonemia as a typical adverse effect.

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine can cause liver dysfunction but is less likely to cause hyperammonemia. It is more commonly associated with blood dyscrasias such as agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia.

 

Option D. Topiramate: This medication is not commonly associated with liver dysfunction or hyperammonemia. It has other side effects, such as weight loss, paresthesias, and cognitive slowing, but liver issues are not typically seen.

Therefore, in the context of a patient with mood disorder presenting with liver dysfunction and hyperammonemia, valproate is the most likely cause among the options provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproate can cause hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia, making it the most likely culprit in patients presenting with these conditions while on medication for mood disorders.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. 

  • Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life.

  • Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. 

  • Diagnosis:

    • Laboratory studies may reveal an increased white blood cell count, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and an elevated C-reactive protein.

    • A needle aspirate may grossly resemble pus.

    • Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. 

 

 

  • The image provided in the question shows a tumor composed of numerous small, relatively uniform, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm. This is the classic "small round blue cell tumor" appearance, which is typical of Ewing sarcoma.

 

  • Markers/Cytogenetics:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is part of a family of peripheral neuroectodermal tumors (PNET) that share a common cytogenetic translocation of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11:22).

  • MIC2 (CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y. This is a highly characteristic and almost universally positive marker for Ewing sarcoma. It is often used as the primary diagnostic marker.

  • Synaptophysin is more commonly associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but it can be focally positive in some Ewing sarcomas, reflecting its neuroectodermal origin. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma (NB) is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor. It is classified as an embryonal neuroendocrine tumor, originating from neural crest progenitor cells. Hence, it can occur anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system, including the superior cervical, paraspinal, and celiac ganglia; the majority arise in the adrenal glands. The most important biological marker is MYCN. Patients with the MYCN gene tend to have rapid progression of cancer and poor outcomes. Other biological markers linked to poor prognosis include lack of expression of glycoprotein CD 44, elevated levels of telomerase RNA, elevated levels of LDH, serum ferritin, and serum neuron-specific enolase. 90% patients have elevations in vanillyl mandelic acid and homovanillic acid in the urine. Histopathology reveal small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (in 10-15% cases), with clustering of cells in the connective tissue. 

 

 

Small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen, presenting as calcification. 

 

 

Codman’s triangle 

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

choices.text: Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease
Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dyspnea on exertion for 1 month. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy. Identify the histopathological finding given below and the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease

 

The lesion shown in the histopathological slide is Aschoff's body and the most probable diagnosis is rheumatic heart disease (RHD).

 

Aschoff's bodies have the following components:

 

  • Anitschkow cells or plump macrophages
  • Abundant cytoplasm
  • Caterpillar cells - refer to centrally condensed chromatin into slender, wavy ribbons
  • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis
  • Aschoff's giant cells - multinucleated larger macrophages
  • T-cells
  • Plasma cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis: While mitral stenosis can result from calcification, it is more typically associated with chronic rheumatic heart disease, which involves Aschoff bodies rather than calcification alone.

 

Option C. Granuloma; Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, but it does not present with Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Non-caseating granuloma: Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis typically presents with caseating granulomas, not Aschoff bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies are indicative of Rheumatic heart disease (RHD), and their presence supports the diagnosis in a patient with clinical features such as mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1044

questions.text: The structures marked in the image below are found in the epithelial lining of all of the following sites, except? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epididymis

 

The picture depicts an arrow mark pointing in the direction of the cilia. All of the structures listed as choices have ciliated lining epithelia, with the exception of the epididymis, which has pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia, that’s play a role in sperm maturation and storage.

 

The given image is a histological section of the epididymis showing the pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia.

 

 

Cilia are minute hair-like projections, while stereocilia are very long, thick microvilli measuring about 5-10 um in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oviduct (Fallopian Tube): The oviduct, also known as the Fallopian tube, is a part of the female reproductive system. It contains ciliated epithelium, which helps in the transport of the egg from the ovary to the uterus. The cilia in the oviduct assist in moving the egg and help in the fertilization process.

 

Option C. Bronchi: The bronchi are part of the respiratory system and are responsible for conducting air to and from the lungs. They contain ciliated epithelium to help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Ependyma : it is a type of neuroglial cell that lines the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. It contains ciliated epithelium, which assists in the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciliated epithelium:

 

  • The epithelium bears cilia, which moves in a coordinated fashion, and help in the movement of the mucus, or propel the movement of any other structures such as ova or spermatozoa.
  • The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.
  • The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the trachea and in large bronchi.

choices.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers
Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers
Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.text: What information is conveyed by the graph presented below? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers 

 

The given Box and Whisker plot depicts different types of data distributions:

 

  1. Normal distribution - The median is in the middle of the box, with whiskers of equal length.
  2. Positively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the bottom of the box, with a longer whisker on the upper end.
  3. Negatively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the top of the box, with a longer whisker on the lower end.
  4. Normal distribution with outliers - The median is in the middle of the box, with equal whisker lengths and the presence of outliers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and Whisker plot

 

  • A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles.
  • It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides.
  • The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3)
  • The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles
  • The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution.
  • The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.

questions.text: Which vector is responsible for transmitting Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mites.

 

Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a type of rickettsial disease. The primary vector responsible for transmitting Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi is the trombiculid mite, commonly known as a chigger. These mites are parasitic larvae that bite humans and other animals, transmitting the bacteria through their saliva during feeding.

 

Scrub typhus is prevalent in areas with dense scrub vegetation, hence the name. Rodents often serve as the reservoir hosts for the bacteria, maintaining the infection cycle in nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Louse: Lice are vectors for other rickettsial diseases, such as epidemic typhus (Rickettsia prowazekii), but not for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Flea: Fleas are vectors for diseases like murine typhus (Rickettsia typhi) but are not involved in the transmission of scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Ticks: Ticks transmit various rickettsial diseases, including Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii), but not scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi, is transmitted by the trombiculid mite, making mites the vector responsible for this disease.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic came with complaints of agitation, disorientation, hallucination, fever, hypertension, and diaphoresis after stopping alcohol intake for 48 hours. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

Delirium tremens (DT) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that usually occurs 48 to 96 hours after cessation of heavy, prolonged alcohol use. It is characterized by agitation, disorientation, hallucinations, fever, hypertension, and diaphoresis, which indicate autonomic instability. Delirium tremens is a medical emergency and can be life-threatening without appropriate treatment.

 

The first-line treatment for delirium tremens is benzodiazepines, particularly diazepam.

 

In patients with liver cirrhosis, shorter-acting benzodiazepines like oxazepam, temazepam, or lorazepam are preferred due to their safer profile in hepatic impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke Encephalopathy: This condition is characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia due to thiamine deficiency but does not typically present with autonomic instability.

 

Option C. Korsakoff Psychosis: This is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe thiamine deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholism, but it does not present with the acute autonomic instability seen in delirium tremens.

 

Option D. Withdrawal seizures: These can occur within 6 to 48 hours after alcohol cessation but are not associated with the severe autonomic instability and other symptoms of delirium tremens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium tremens is a severe, life-threatening form of alcohol withdrawal that occurs 48 to 96 hours after cessation of alcohol intake, characterized by autonomic instability, agitation, disorientation, and hallucinations. The first-line treatment is benzodiazepines, particularly diazepam.

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?(NEET  PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

 

The given clinical scenario of rice-water stools is suggestive of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by the organism acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors.

 

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice water stools) associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary edema and arrhythmias are some of the complications.

 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea.

 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludes toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells.

 

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

 

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Medical management includes erythromycin or azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2 ganglioside receptor: Not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While it is a component of cell membranes, it is not the receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Option D. Cerebroganglioside: Also not a receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding that cholera toxin acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors is crucial for grasping the pathophysiological basis of cholera. This interaction triggers a cascade of events leading to the massive, life-threatening secretory diarrhea that characterizes the disease. Proper hydration and antibiotics like erythromycin are key to treatment.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her school going nephew who lives in the same house has contracted varicella. A blood sample is taken for Antibodies against varicella. The report is negative. What does this signify? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Susceptible to chicken pox

 

Explanation:

 

Chickenpox in Pregnancy:

 

  • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV).
  • A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox.
  • If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG).
  • VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact.
  • Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes:
    • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks.
    • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome.
  • If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immune to chickenpox: A negative antibody test does not signify immunity; it signifies susceptibility.

 

Option C. Susceptible to zoster: Varicella-zoster virus causes both chickenpox (primary infection) and shingles (reactivation). A negative test for varicella antibodies indicates susceptibility to the primary infection (chickenpox), not to shingles.

 

Option D. Immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster would imply prior exposure to the varicella-zoster virus, which is not indicated by a negative varicella antibody test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative varicella antibody test in a pregnant woman indicates that she is susceptible to chickenpox and should receive VZIG if exposed.

 

Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC include all except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 7 days admission in hospital

 

The duration of hospital stay alone does not define grievous hurt under IPC 320. The nature and severity of the injury are the determining factors, not the length of hospitalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC:

 

Option A. Permanent privation of hearing: This is considered grievous hurt as it results in the permanent loss of a sense, causing significant and lasting disability.

 

Option B. Fracture femur: Fracture of the femur is explicitly mentioned under IPC 320 as grievous hurt due to the severity and potential long-term consequences of the injury.

 

Option D. Emasculation: This involves depriving a man of his masculine vigour and is considered grievous hurt due to the significant physical and psychological impact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grievous hurt under IPC 320 involves injuries that cause permanent disability, severe bodily pain, or life-altering effects. Hospital stay duration alone does not qualify an injury as grievous hurt unless accompanied by a severe or specified injury under the law.

questions.text: Bacillus anthracis is which category of bioweapon? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Category A

 

In Bioterrorism, there is intentional and deliberate release of biological agents (bacteria, viruses, or their toxins) to cause mass illness or death of people, animals, or plants

 

Bioweapons, or biological agents, are classified into three categories (A, B, and C) based on their risk to national security and public health. Bacillus anthracis, the bacterium that causes anthrax, is classified as a Category A bioweapon.

 

Category A:

 

  • Highest Priority: These agents pose the greatest risk to national security and public health because they can be easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person, result in high mortality rates, and have the potential for major public health impact.
  • Examples: The mnemonic "Play with small, fine, bad" can help remember the agents in this category.
    • P: Plague (Yersinia pestis)
    • V: Viral hemorrhagic fevers
    • Small: Smallpox (Variola major)
    • Fine: Filoviridae (Ebola, Marburg)
    • 2B: Botulinum toxin, Bunyaviruses
    • 2A: Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis), Arenaviruses
    • T: Tularemia (Francisella tularensis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Category B: These agents are the second highest priority and are moderately easy to disseminate. They result in moderate morbidity rates and low mortality rates. Examples –

 

 

Option C. Category C: These agents are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of their availability, ease of production, and potential for high morbidity and mortality rates. Examples –

 

 

Option D. Category D: This option is not part of the standard classification for bioweapons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Bacillus anthracis is classified as a Category A bioweapon due to its high potential for causing significant public health impact through easy dissemination and high mortality rates.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of ptosis and diplopia that worsens with activity and improves with rest. What is the most sensitive investigation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) EMG (Electromyography)

 

The symptoms of ptosis and diplopia that worsen with activity and improve with rest are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder caused by autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

 

The most sensitive investigation for myasthenia gravis is single fiber electromyography (SF-EMG), which detects abnormalities in the neuromuscular transmission by measuring the electrical activity of muscle fibers. Even if single fiber EMG is not specifically mentioned, standard EMG is still highly sensitive and appropriate for diagnosing myasthenia gravis. Another practical test used is repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS), which shows a decremental response in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT scan chest: This is usually performed in confirmed myasthenia gravis patients to rule out thymoma, but it is not the most sensitive test for diagnosing the condition itself.

 

Option C. Acetylcholinesterase test: Also known as the edrophonium test or Tensilon test, this can be used to diagnose myasthenia gravis by temporarily improving muscle strength. However, it has variable sensitivity and specificity and is less sensitive than EMG.

 

Option D. Nerve conduction velocity: This test is more relevant in the diagnosis of neuropathies, particularly demyelinating neuropathies, where conduction velocities are decreased. It is not the most sensitive test for myasthenia gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most sensitive investigation for diagnosing myasthenia gravis is electromyography (EMG), particularly single fiber EMG, which detects abnormalities in neuromuscular transmission.

choices.text: It should not be given with pyrazinamide
It should be taken empty stomach
It is given as a loading dose

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis is being treated with voriconazole. He has been on the medication for two weeks and comes to the clinic for a follow-up. During the visit, he asks about the specific guidelines and considerations for taking voriconazole to ensure its effectiveness and safety. Which of the following statements is true about voriconazole? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is given as a loading dose
 

Voriconazole requires a loading dose to rapidly achieve therapeutic levels in the body. This is a crucial aspect of its administration, especially in acute settings where rapid antifungal activity is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with pyrazinamide: There is no significant interaction between voriconazole and pyrazinamide. Voriconazole does interact with many other medications due to its effect on cytochrome P450 enzymes, but pyrazinamide is not one of the primary concerns.

 

Option B. It should be taken empty stomach: Voriconazole can be taken either with or without food, but it is generally recommended to take it one hour before or one hour after a meal to ensure optimal absorption. While this is important, it is not the most critical consideration compared to therapeutic drug monitoring.

 

Option D. It requires therapeutic drug monitoring: While therapeutic drug monitoring can be important for voriconazole, especially in certain patient populations, it is not as universally mandated or emphasized as the initial loading dose regimen in standard treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the statement that voriconazole "is given as a loading dose" is the most universally applicable and critical aspect of its administration, especially for ensuring rapid therapeutic levels in treating fungal infections.

questions.text: A biostatistician is reviewing data from a recent research study. She observes that the confidence interval (CI) for one of the primary outcomes is quite wide. Which of the following factors is least likely to contribute to the widening of the confidence interval? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Increasing sample size

 

A confidence interval (CI) provides a range of values within which we can be reasonably certain that the population parameter lies. The width of the CI can be influenced by several factors:

 

  • Increase in sample size: As the sample size increases, the margin of error decreases, resulting in a narrower confidence interval. Therefore, an increase in sample size is least likely to contribute to the widening of the CI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease in sample size: A smaller sample size increases the margin of error, leading to a wider confidence interval. This is because with fewer observations, there is more uncertainty about the estimate.

 

Option C. Increase in variability: Higher variability in the data increases the margin of error, which in turn widens the confidence interval. Variability affects the precision of the estimate.

 

Option D. Increase in confidence level: Increasing the confidence level (e.g., from 95% to 99%) requires a larger range to ensure that the true population parameter is captured with greater certainty, thus widening the confidence interval.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A smaller sample size or a higher variability will result in a wider confidence interval with a larger margin of error
  • As sample size increases, the margin of error decreases
  • As the variability in the population increases, the margin of error increases
  • As you increase the confidence level (e.g., 95% to 99%) while holding the sample size and variability constant, the confidence interval widens
  • Smaller the SD, narrower is Confidence interval

questions.text: Identify this instrument: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Verres needle

 

Explanation:

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Verres needle, which is commonly used in laparoscopic surgeries to create pneumoperitoneum. Pneumoperitoneum is the introduction of gas, typically carbon dioxide, into the peritoneal cavity. This step is crucial as it provides the necessary space for the surgeon to visualize and operate within the abdomen.

 

The Verres needle is inserted into the abdominal cavity, and once its correct placement is confirmed, carbon dioxide is introduced through the needle to inflate the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leech Wilkinson cannula: This is not typically used for creating pneumoperitoneum.

 

 

Option C. Laparoscope: This is an instrument used for visual inspection of the abdominal cavity but is introduced after pneumoperitoneum is established.

 

 

Option D. Trocar and cannula: These are used for the insertion of various instruments into the abdomen during laparoscopic surgery, but the creation of pneumoperitoneum is done first using the Verres needle.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Verres needle is essential for creating pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries, allowing for the necessary space for safe and effective surgical procedures within the abdominal cavity.

questions.text: A dead body is recovered from a river. The body has signs of antemortem drowning and also has multiple wounds as shown below. What can be the cause of these wounds? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Self-inflicted

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows multiple superficial, parallel incised wounds on the forearm, which are characteristic of hesitation marks. Hesitation marks are typically seen in cases of suicide attempts where the individual makes multiple superficial cuts while hesitating to make a final, deeper cut.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Active self-defense wound: Incorrect because active self-defense wounds are found on the front of the hands and forearms and usually involve a struggle, not multiple, superficial, parallel cuts.

 

Option C. Postmortem artifact: Incorrect because postmortem artifacts do not present as multiple, organized, parallel incised wounds.

 

Option D. Passive self-defense wound: Incorrect because passive self-defense wounds are found on the back of the hands and forearms and are typically blunt force injuries, not superficial cuts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key points to understand about the different types of wounds:

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee and a high fever. X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Aspirate from the joint will most likely show: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Salmonella

 

  • The clinical presentation strongly suggests acute osteomyelitis, and joint aspirate analysis is likely to reveal Salmonella as the causative pathogen.
  • The peripheral smear findings are indicative of sickle cell anemia, a hematological disorder characterized by a variety of complications such as acute painful episodes, priapism, stroke, leg ulcers, and acute chest syndrome (presenting as pneumonia-like symptoms with fever, cough, and hypoxia).
  • Acute osteomyelitis is an infection that affects the bone and is more commonly observed in children.
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the primary pathogen responsible for osteomyelitis, in patients with sickle cell anemia, Salmonella is often the causative agent.
  • Additionally, other bacteria such as Hemophilus influenzae, E. coli, Streptococcus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa can also cause the condition.
  • The infection can spread through the blood (hematogenous route) or through external sources like open fractures, iatrogenic interventions, or from nearby infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus. It is the most common organism to cause acute/subacute/chronic osteomyelitis, post-traumatic and post-surgical osteomyelitis in all age groups. It also causes acute pyogenic infections of spine.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type. Sternoclavicular joint is one of the rare location for hematogenous osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of milk production in the correct sequence: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

 

  1. Galactopoiesis
  2. Lactogenesis
  3. Mammogenesis
  4. Lactation
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 1, 4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence of milk production involves several stages, starting from the development of the mammary glands to the actual ejection of milk. These stages are:

 

3. Mammogenesis : This is the development of the mammary glands, which begins at birth but continues significantly during puberty. The breast tissue matures and prepares for potential milk production.

 

2. Lactogenesis : This stage refers to the initiation of milk synthesis. It involves hormonal changes that stimulate the mammary glands to start producing milk. Lactogenesis typically begins during the late stages of pregnancy and continues after childbirth.

 

1. Galactopoiesis : This is the maintenance of milk production after lactogenesis has initiated. It involves the continued synthesis and secretion of milk, which is essential for sustaining milk supply during breastfeeding.

 

4. Lactation: This refers to the process of milk ejection and feeding the baby. It encompasses the baby's suckling, which stimulates further milk production and ejection through the let-down reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of milk production involves mammogenesis, lactogenesis, galactopoiesis, and finally lactation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liddle’s Syndrome

 

Liddle's syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by early-onset hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to a gain-of-function mutation in the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). This mutation leads to increased sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron, which indirectly causes potassium loss and elevated blood pressure. The syndrome mimics hyperaldosteronism but occurs in the absence of elevated aldosterone levels.

 

 

Hypokalemia + HTN causes:

 

Aldosterone Activation

 

  • Liddle syndrome (ENaC channel Gain of function mutation)
  • Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess (AME) (11Beta-HSD loss of function)
    • ↓11-βHSD→↑Cortisol →↑Stimulation of MR receptor → HTN + Hypokalemia + alkalosis
  • Geller Syndrome (Mineralocorticoid mutation responding to progesterone): Presents in pregnancy. Rx with specific drug like Finerenone.
  • Glucocorticoid remediable Hyperaldosteronism (GRA): Chimeric gene b/w CYP11B1, B2 causing ACTH driven hyperaldosteronism.
  • Primary Hyperaldosteronism

 

Other options:

 

Option A : Bartter syndrome mimics loop diuretics which occur due to loss of function of Na+-K+-2Cl- transporter at the Loop of Henle. Often patient has NORMOTENSION.

 

Option C : Gitelman syndrome mimics thiazide diuretic occurring due to loss of function mutation of Na+-Cl- transporter in DCT. Both Bartter and Gitelman syndrome are normotensive

 

Option D : Gordon syndrome is opposite of Gitelman syndrome characterized by Gain of function mutation to Na+-Cl- channel which occurs either due to GOF of WNT1 pathway (OR) LOF of WNT 4 pathway, leads to inhibition of ROMK channel causing HYPERKALEMIA.

 

Note: Gordon = HTN + Hyperkalemia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liddle's syndrome is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to increased activity of sodium channels in the distal nephron, not due to increased aldosterone, distinguishing it from other similar electrolyte disorders.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/ Physiology of Kidney/Chap 309 - Table 309-1

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for patent ductus arteriosus, which structure in close relation to it can be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth, leaving an open connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. Surgical correction of this defect involves closing the ductus arteriosus.

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, loops under the arch of the aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum (the remnant of the ductus arteriosus). Due to its close proximity to the ductus arteriosus, this nerve is at risk of being damaged during surgical procedures aimed at correcting PDA. Injury to this nerve can result in hoarseness, voice changes, or even vocal cord paralysis due to its role in innervating the muscles of the larynx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagus nerve: While the vagus nerve is in the vicinity, it does not have the same close relationship with the ductus arteriosus as the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. The vagus nerve primarily runs along the side of the neck and thorax without looping directly near the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option C. Right recurrent laryngeal nerve: The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the right subclavian artery and does not pass near the ductus arteriosus, making it less likely to be damaged during surgery on the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option D. Phrenic nerve: The phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, runs more anteriorly in the thorax and does not have a close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus, thus it is not at significant risk during PDA surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is at significant risk of injury during surgical procedures for patent ductus arteriosus due to its close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

In patients with AIDS, regardless of their CD4 count, the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae. This organism is a leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients.

 

The clinical presentation of fever, productive cough, bronchial breath sounds, and right lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray is consistent with bacterial pneumonia. While Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly known as Pneumocystis carinii) is a common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients with low CD4 counts, it typically presents with bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray and less commonly with lobar consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is common in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm³. It usually presents with diffuse bilateral infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia, especially post-viral or in hospital-acquired cases, but it is not the most common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients. It can also present with abscess formation and necrotizing pneumonia, which were not described here.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia, especially in younger patients, but it is less likely in this immunocompromised patient with typical lobar consolidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with AIDS, Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia, regardless of the CD4 count. This should be a primary consideration when evaluating pneumonia in this population.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented after a motor vehicle accident to the emergency. On examination, the right lower limb was longer than the left, abducted and externally rotated. What can be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior hip dislocation

 

ANTERIOR HIP DISLOCATION

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.
  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • Hip dislocations are most common in young adult males and are most often the result of motor vehicle accidents. 
  • The patients present with hip and leg in extension, abduction, and external rotation.

 

 

  • Radiological findings include loss of congruence of femoral head with acetabulum, disruption of shenton's line, femoral head appears larger than contralateral femoral head, and femoral head lies medial or inferior to acetabulum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve injury: Femoral nerve damage can occur from an injury or prolonged compression. Typically, damage and dysfunction of the femoral nerve are associated with the leg weakness and sensation changes. Injury of the femoral is uncommon but may be injured by a stab, gunshot wounds, or a pelvic fracture. It can also be damaged during hip replacement, abdominal, and pelvic surgeries. The patient presents with poor flexion of the hip because of paralysis of the iliacus, psoas and sartorius muscles. There is an inability to extend the knee because of paralysis of the quadriceps femoris. There is sensory decline over the anterior and medial aspects of the thigh, medial side of the leg and foot up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint. It does not directly affect the position of the hip or the length appearance of the limb.

 

Option B. Femoral neck fracture: Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. It is commonly seen in the elderly due to low energy falls, and in young patients who perform athletics or due to high-energy trauma. The patient complains of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. The leg appears shortened due to the upward movement of the distal fragment. The key feature is the inability to bear weight and immediate pain.

 

 

Option C. Posterior hip dislocation: It is the Most common hip dislocation (90%). Patients with a posterior dislocation of the hip generally present with a shortened, internally rotated, adducted limb in slight flexion. If the hip is adducted at the time of injury, a pure dislocation occurs, whereas a neutral position or abduction leads to fracture dislocation. It is associated with a fracture of the femoral head or acetabulum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The limb appears lengthened and in FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation) deformity in anterior dislocation of the hip following a motor vehicle accident.
  • Thus, in the given scenario, the patient has anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

 

The best advice for the exposed students is to receive antibiotic prophylaxis. This is recommended for close contacts of a person with meningococcal meningitis, such as household members, intimate contacts, and anyone who has had direct contact with the patient's oral secretions. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated as soon as possible after exposure and can be effective in preventing secondary cases of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Two doses of polysaccharide vaccine: While vaccination is important, it takes time to provide protection. Therefore, it is not the best option for immediate protection in this situation.

 

Option C. Two doses of conjugate vaccine: The conjugate vaccine is recommended for adolescents and children, but similar to the polysaccharide vaccine, it does not provide immediate protection. Antibiotic prophylaxis is still necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Option D. Single dose of meningococcal vaccine: Again, vaccination alone is not sufficient for immediate protection, and antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

choices.text: Green tea increases the risk of diabetes
Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes
Data insufficient to establish causal association
The value (0.84) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.text: A cohort study was carried out involving individuals who consumed green tea and those who did not, aiming to examine its impact on diabetes mellitus. The calculated risk ratio stood at 0.84. Which of the subsequent statements is accurate? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

 

Green tea consumption decreases the risk of DM

 

Relative risk <1 implies negative/inverse association, i.e., risk factor is rather protective for the disease.

 

The risk ratio of 0.84 indicates that the incidence of diabetes mellitus is lower in the group of drinkers of green tea compared to the group of non-drinkers. Therefore, it can be concluded that green tea decreases the risk of diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

 

Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)

questions.text: Iron absorption is decreased by the intake of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tea

 

Explanation:

 

There are several factors that can decrease iron absorption, including phytates (present in cereals and legumes), tannates (present in tea, coffee, and soft drinks), oxalates (present in milk and eggs), and certain medications like tetracycline.

 

The only facilitator of iron absorption is vitamin C or ascorbic acid.

 

Among the given options, tea contains tannates, which are known to inhibit iron absorption. Therefore, the intake of tea decreases iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amla: This option is incorrect because amla is a rich source of vitamin C, which enhances iron absorption.

 

Option B. Sprouts: This option is incorrect because sprouts are a good source of iron.

 

Option D. Lemon: This option is incorrect because lemon is a source of vitamin C, which facilitates iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tea contains tannates, which are compounds that inhibit iron absorption. Consuming tea can decrease the absorption of iron from dietary sources.

questions.text: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Loss of myelin sheath

 

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is primarily characterized by the autoimmune-mediated demyelination of central nervous system neurons. The myelin sheath is crucial for proper and fast electrical conduction along nerve fibers; it facilitates saltatory conduction, which allows the action potential to jump rapidly from one node of Ranvier to the next. The loss of this myelin sheath in MS results in significantly slowed and disrupted nerve signal conduction, which underlies many of the neurological symptoms associated with the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gliosis: Gliosis is not seen in MS but seen in viral encephalitis, Alzheimer's disease, traumatic brain injury, and gliomas

 

Option C. Defect at node of Ranvier: Although alterations in the nodes of Ranvier occur secondary to demyelination, the primary issue is the loss of the myelin sheath itself, not initial defects at the nodes.

 

Option D. Leaky Na+ channel: This option refers to a specific type of channelopathy that isn't characteristic of MS. In MS, the problem is more about the insulation (myelin) around the nerve fibers rather than the ion channels within the nerve cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple sclerosis is characterized by demyelination that results in loss of saltatory conduction occurring from one node of Ranvier to the other.

 

Reference - Harrison/Multiple sclerosis/Chap 444

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Taking CT scan of the patient

 

Taking CT scan of the patient: Incorrect. This is not part of the primary survey. After the primary survey, if the patient is stabilized, a secondary survey is conducted which is a more thorough examination and may involve advanced imaging like CT scans to further delineate injuries.

 

Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

 

Primary survey consists of five components, remembered by the mnemonic "ABCDE":

 

  1. Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection: The first step is to ensure the patient has a patent (open) airway, and to protect the cervical spine in case of potential injury.
  2. Breathing and ventilation: This step includes assessing the patient's breathing and ventilation. This can involve checking for symmetric chest rise, listening for breath sounds, and looking for any signs of respiratory distress or chest injury.
  3. Circulation with haemorrhage control: This involves assessing the patient's circulation and looking for signs of active bleeding. Measures such as fluid resuscitation may be initiated during this step if the patient is in shock.
  4. Disability: This involves a quick evaluation of the patient's neurological status, often using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS).
  5. Exposure/Environmental control: The patient should be fully undressed to allow a complete examination. However, care should be taken to prevent hypothermia, which can worsen outcomes in trauma patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measuring blood pressure: This is a part of assessing Circulation.

 

Option B. Removing clothes to inspect for wounds: This is a part of Exposure/Environmental control. It's crucial to remove clothing so that injuries aren't missed. However, while ensuring exposure, care should also be taken to maintain the patient's body temperature and prevent hypothermia.

 

Option D. Checking airway patency: This is part of Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection. Ensuring a clear airway is a top priority. Airway obstruction takes least time to death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary survey in trauma care includes Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure/Environmental control. Advanced imaging studies like CT scans are part of the secondary survey, conducted after initial stabilization.

questions.text: Anenecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in which week of gestation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4th week

 

The neural tube closes by the end of the fourth week of gestation. Anencephaly occurs when the neural tube fails to close properly during this critical period.

 

Anencephaly is a serious birth defect in which a baby is born without parts of the brain and skull. It occurs when the upper part of the neural tube fails to close. The neural tube is the structure in a developing embryo that eventually becomes the baby's brain, spinal cord, and surrounding tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ananecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in 4th week of gestation.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of fatigue, lethargy, pallor, and right index finger pain. Biochemical analysis showed raised indirect bilirubin. What can be the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sickle cell anemia

 

Explanation:

 

The combination of symptoms, including fatigue, lethargy, pallor (suggesting anemia), right index finger pain, and elevated indirect bilirubin levels (indicating jaundice), strongly points toward sickle cell anemia as the underlying diagnosis.

Sickle cell anemia is a hemolytic anemia characterized by the production of abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells, which can lead to vaso-occlusive crises and ischemic damage.

 

The presence of right index finger pain is a crucial clue, as it may be a manifestation of dactylitis or hand-foot syndrome, which is commonly seen in sickle cell anemia patients. This condition arises due to the involvement of small blood vessels in the hands and feet, leading to inflammation and severe pain.

 

Additionally, the hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) associated with sickle cell anemia results in anemia and elevated indirect bilirubin levels, causing jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thalassemia: While thalassemia is also a type of hemolytic anemia, it does not typically present with the characteristic hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis seen in sickle cell anemia.

 

Option C. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves the destruction of red blood cells by the body's own immune system. It does not typically cause the specific symptom of index finger pain.

 

Option D. PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria): PNH is a rare acquired disorder characterized by the destruction of red blood cells, but it does not typically present with the combination of symptoms seen in this case, particularly the right index finger pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with anemia, jaundice, and specific finger pain (dactylitis or hand-foot syndrome), sickle cell anemia should be strongly considered as the underlying diagnosis.

choices.text: CRP has no association with risk of MI/stroke
Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke
Increase in CRP decreases the risk of Ml/stroke
In group 1, there is no risk of MI/stroke

questions.text:
A researcher is investigating whether a correlation exists between CRP values and the likelihood of experiencing myocardial infarction or stroke. The participants in the study were split into five groups and the following table is formed based on the study results. Among the provided options, which statement accurately reflects the connection between CRP levels and the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke? [NEET PG 2021]

(CRP à C-reactive protein)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke  

 

The given study results show Relative risk values which are > 1 in majority of the groups.

 

Also, with the increase in CRP levels, relative risk is also showing an uprise. Hence, it can be implied that CRP levels have a positive association with risk of MI/Stroke.

 

Among the given options, the best answer will be option B.

 

 

Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b)]/ c/(c+d)] where,

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased CRP levels are positively associated with an increased risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and stroke. As CRP levels rise, the relative risk of these conditions also increases.

questions.text: Cowden syndrome is associated with mutation in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PTEN

 

Cowden syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by multiple tumor-like growths and an increased risk of certain cancers. It is associated with mutations in the PTEN gene, a tumor suppressor gene. This mutation leads to dysregulated cell growth and survival, contributing to the development of benign and malignant tumors, particularly in the breast, thyroid, and endometrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. WT1: Associated with Wilms' tumor.

 

Option C. p53: Commonly mutated in various cancers but not specifically associated with Cowden syndrome.

 

Option D. Ras: Linked to a variety of cancers through different mechanisms but not directly to Cowden syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During the forensic examination of dry semen from undergarment of a rape victim. What specific test is employed to ascertain the presence of sperm? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio test

 

When examining dry semen stains found on the undergarment of a rape victim, the Barberio test is the specific test employed to ascertain the presence of sperm. Although the Barberio test is not considered the most reliable test for semen, it can still yield positive results in dry stains, making it the most suitable choice among the given options for this particular scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Acid phosphatase test: The acid phosphatase test is indeed a good test for detecting semen, but it is not the best choice for dry stains. The activity of acid phosphatase decreases rapidly with time, making it less effective in detecting the presence of sperm in older, dry semen stains.

 

Option. C. Papanicolaou smear: The Papanicolaou (Pap) smear is not a test used for detecting semen. It is a cytological test used primarily for screening cervical cancer and other abnormalities in the female reproductive system.

 

Option. D. Florence test: The Florence test is another test used for detecting semen, but it is not mentioned as the most appropriate test for dry semen stains in the given scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When examining dry semen stains, such as those found on the undergarment of a rape victim, the Barberio test is the specific test employed to ascertain the presence of sperm, as it can yield positive results even in dry stains.
